snippet: An inquiry into corruption at CCTV has shaken up the nation’s most influential news organization, with reports involving a seamy mix of celebrities, sex and bribery.
abstract: Corruption investigations at China's state television network China Central Television has led to detention of at least 15 senior executives, leaving employees on edge; network has been most powerful propaganda tool in Communist Party's arsenal; focus of inquiry is corrupt business practices and cozy relationships news anchors and executives have with party leaders; party is seizing investigation as chance to reinforce network's propaganda role.

byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times contributed reporting. Mia Li contributed research.

lead_paragraph: An inquiry into corruption at CCTV has shaken up the nation’s most influential news organization, with reports involving a seamy mix of celebrities, sex and bribery.

headline.main: CCTV, China’s Propaganda Tool, Finds Itself at Center of Antigraft Drive
headline.print_headline: Suddenly Strict, Beijing Slaps Its Mouthpiece
